title: How Envato succeeded without external investors
text:
Michael Bailey Rich List Editor Oct 23, 2019 — 12.00am Share

Cyan Ta’eed feels lucky, and perhaps even blessed, that her business has survived – and thrived.

The 38-year-old acknowledges there’s been plenty of hard work in building Envato, the marketplace for digital assets she started with husband Collis in her parents’ Bondi Junction garage in 2006.

It’s a global powerhouse that turned over $134 million in 2017-18, employs nearly 500 people and is valued by our 2019 Financial Review Young Rich List researchers at $1.1 billion. The company's success has placed the couple in fourth spot on this year's list with a combined wealth of $799 million.

Yet luck has had a role to play. “I’ve seen how it’s gone for other founders,” Ta’eed says. “Their ideas were as good as ours, they had the drive and for whatever reason, the market just wasn’t with them.

“The longer I’ve been in business, the more I think what an anomaly it is that we have gotten to Envato’s scale with no external investment. We’ve won the lottery of life here, and there’s a responsibility that comes with that.”

The phrase “profit with purpose” buzzes in business circles. But the talk is walked by Envato’s founding couple, who together own 68 per cent of the business and sit on its board alongside Collis’ older brother Vahid, and father Fuad. (Vahid and another founder, Jun Rung, share the remaining 32 per cent).

When they decided to start an Envato profit-share scheme in 2016-17, they didn’t just carve up that year’s black ink. They calculated 5 per cent of each year’s pre-tax profits all the way back to 2006, and from retained earnings they allocated it to every staff member who worked that year, regardless of whether they were still Envato employees.

About $13 million went to about 1000 people. “That was a fun email to send,” Collis Ta’eed told the The Australian Financial Review in April. “I had former colleagues ringing to check it wasn’t a phishing scam.”
description: The garage start-up Cyan and Collis Ta'eed founded has grown to be a global powerhouse worth $1.1 billion. Now the Young Rich Listers are giving back plenty of the proceeds.
